content.description:
Neptune at the Surface of the Sea

Sic cunctus pelagipelagus, -i, n. = mare, -is cecidit fragorfragor, -oris, m.: noise, crash, aequora postquam 
prospiciensprospicio, -ere = aspicio, -ere genitorgenitor, -oris, m.: creator1 caeloque invectusinveho, -ere, -vexi, -vectum: to carry aperto 
flectit equos currucurru = curruique volans dat loralorum, -i, n.: rein, leather strap secundosecundus, -a, -um, adj.: obedient.
 1:This word refers here to the god Neptune.↩
content.question: In line 3, curruque volans dat lora secundo is translated

choices.label: and, after his chariot becomes obedient, he, willing, gives it free rein
and while flying, he will obediently give free rein to his chariot
and while flying, he gives free rein to an obedient chariot
and, willing, he will give free rein to an obedient chariot

content.answer: and while flying, he gives free rein to an obedient chariot

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2
